newsitem.title: USA: U.S. West Coast prods turn narrowly mixed late.
newsitem.headline: U.S. West Coast prods turn narrowly mixed late.

text.p: Prices for U.S. West Coast products turned narrowly mixed in thin late trade, as a softer futures market was offset by concerns about tight distillate stocks.
"These are levels we moved to yesterday and it's still talked at those levels," one trader said.

West Coast traders noted that despite a 3.2 million barrel rise in stocks last week, distillates nationwide remained a significant 18 million below year-ago levels, according to data released from the American Petroleum Institute.

"We're going into the winter short," one California trader said, noting the state's diesel demand would increase in the next few weeks because of harvesting. Heating demand from the cooler Pacific Northwest would also increase consumption.
Locally, distillate inventories remained 715,000 barrels below year ago, at 10.9 million barrels.
Traders said distillates were tight on lingering production problems at Arco and Mobil's Los Angeles refineries and Chevron's northern California plant.
They said a fluid catalytic cracker at the Mobil refinery was expected back late this week.
Los Angeles CARB diesel rose one cent late to 76/77 cents a gallon, while "EPA," or low sulphur diesel also added a cent to reach 71.50/72.50 cents.
The spread between more expensive CARB-grade gasolines and conventional grades stayed unusually narrow Wednesday, with refinery problems making the cost of conventional to go up.

Bids for Los Angeles conventional-grade gasoline added a one cent loss to their earlier fall of 0.50 cent. The grade ranged between 68 and 69 cents a gallon as NYMEX October crude settled 16 cents lower on the day at $23.24 a barrel.
NYMEX October gasoline settled unchanged at 62.96 cents.
Offers for CARB-grade unleaded in L.A. dropped a half cent to 71.50 cents.
